headline.main: Fat; The Secret Life Of a Potent Cell

docs.abstract: Fat cells, once thought to be inert, are now considered endocrine organ by many biologists because of their ability to release hormones directly into bloodstream; Dr Philipp E Scherer, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, New York, cell biology professor who has been studying fat cells for past 10 years, explains new research into fat cells and implications for increasingly obese world; World Health Organization's list of top 10 global health risks includes obesity and heart disease and high blood pressure, two complications of obesity; fat cell biology described; risks of too much visceral or abdominal fat over same degree of subcutaneous fat discussed; photo; drawing (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: They are the building blocks of flab, the wages of cheesecake, the bloated little sacks of grease that make more of us -- more than we can fit into our pants. Scorned and despised, they are sucked out surgically by the billions from bulging backsides, bellies and thighs. But they are not without admirers.

headline.main: Too Little Fat Can Be as Bad as Too Much

docs.abstract: Lipodystrophy, disease that robs body of fat and is often associated with HIV infection, has risks similar to obesity; Professor Abhimanyu Garg of University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center is leading expert on lipodystrophy; explains disorder and describes differences in fat distribution and effects; link between HIV infection and lipodystrophy discussed (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: To unzip the blanket of fat encasing the body and step free is the fantasy of many overweight people. For a few people, though, life without that layer of fat is a sobering and not very pleasant reality. They are the victims of a disease called lipodystrophy, which strips the body of fat either in just a few areas, or everywhere.

headline.main: Bypass Is Called a Last Resort

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas H Inge, University of Cincinnati researcher, leads study on use of gastric bypass operations to treat obesity in young people; study, published in journal Pediatrics, suggests risks and benefits of surgery are same for young people and adults, but suggests that surgery be restricted to those over age 13 with severe obesity; also recommends that surgery be delayed until patient is 95 percent of their predicted adult height; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Gastric bypass operations may be an appropriate treatment for obesity in teenagers, but only for those who are severely overweight and ready to make a lifelong commitment to dietary changes, according to a study being released today in the journal Pediatrics. Dr. Thomas H. Inge of the University of Cincinnati, the study's lead author, said that he had seen reports of several hundred cases in which gastric bypass had been performed on adolescents but that he believed the procedure was becoming far more common than that.
docs.snippet: Gastric bypass operations may be an appropriate treatment for obesity in teenagers, but only for those who are severely overweight and ready to make a lifelong commitment to dietary changes, according to a study being released today in the journal...

docs.abstract: Virginia Heffernan chronicle fat books reviews recent books on human body weight: The Obesity Myth: Why America's Obesssion With Weight Is Hazardous to Your Health by Paul Campos; The Fat Girl's Guide to Life by Wendy Shanker; It Was Food Versus Me...And I Won by Nancy Goodman; Food and Loathing: A Life Measured Out in Calories by Betsy Lerner; Passing for Thin: Losing Half My Weight and Finding Myself by Frances Kuffel; Slim to None: A Journey Through the Wasteland of Anorexia Treatment by Jennifer Hendricks; Homesick: A Memoir of Family, Food, and Finding Hope by Jenny Lauren; and Food Fight: The Inside Story of the Food Industry, America's Obesity Crisis, and What We Can Do About It by Kelly D Brownell and Katherine Battle Horgen; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHICH is the more expedient solution, the one that will produce greater happiness -- becoming thin; or deciding, through rarefied cultural perspective, that being thin doesn't matter? A dozen recent ruminations about human body weight -- memoirs, science, self-help -- trip grievously on this dilemma, stumbling between the options, getting lost even while pretending to reach certainty and, furthermore, victory. Whether viewed as an affliction of the body or the mind, fat is apparently an intractable problem. ''We still have no idea how to make fat people thin,'' Paul Campos writes in THE OBESITY MYTH: Why America's Obsession With Weight Is Hazardous to Your Health (Gotham, $25), pronouncing heraldically that ''tolerance toward an almost wholly benign form of human diversity is the least we should expect of ourselves.'' We don't tolerate it, however, if this new shelf of books can be believed. We can't be fat; we must be fat. This pathos of American abundance works wonderfully in memoir, and some of these falsely triumphant books are stirring and even enlightening, bad faith being of course a central element of weight control, with all its cheating and black-is-slimming and cloaking of vanity in moral terms.

byline.original: By MICHELLE SALE and JAVAID KHAN

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students research topics related to ice cream and create a news magazine program based on their research. Then students develop public service announcements promoting ice cream consumption.
docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students research topics related to ice cream and create a news magazine program based on their research. Then students develop public service announcements promoting ice cream consumption.
